articles.headline: After Freeze, Settlement Building Booms in West Bank
articles.snippet: In the three months since Israel ended its freeze, construction is booming in places that are least likely to be part of Israel after any two-state peace deal.
articles.abstract: In the three months since Israel ended its freeze, construction is booming in places that are least likely to be part of Israel after any two-state peace deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In the three months since Israel ended its settlement construction freeze in the West Bank, causing the Palestinians to withdraw from peace talks, a settlement-building boom has begun, especially in more remote communities that are least likely to be part of Israel after any two-state peace deal.

articles.headline: U.S. Says China Fund Breaks Rules
articles.snippet: Washington asked for World Trade Organization talks after accusing Beijing of granting illegal subsidies.
articles.abstract: Washington asked for World Trade Organization talks after accusing Beijing of granting illegal subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration filed a case against China with the World Trade Organization on Wednesday, siding with an American labor union, the United Steelworkers, in accusing Beijing of illegally subsidizing the production of wind power equipment.

articles.headline: Computers That Trade on the News
articles.snippet: Traders are using software to track news, blogs and even Twitter posts to identify shifts in market sentiment.
articles.abstract: Traders are using software to track news, blogs and even Twitter posts to identify shifts in market sentiment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The number-crunchers on Wall Street are starting to crunch something else: the news.

articles.headline: Sizing a Sensor: No Easy Way
articles.snippet: Sensor size is important in pocket cameras, but figuring out that size among various products is baffling.
articles.abstract: Sensor size is important in pocket cameras, but figuring out that size among various products is baffling.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, you get two columns in one.

articles.headline: Alabama Town’s Failed Pension Is a Warning
articles.snippet: As cities and states struggle to pay for pensions, Prichard, Ala., is a worst case. Some retirees have become destitute.
articles.abstract: As cities and states struggle to pay for pensions, Prichard, Ala., is a worst case. Some retirees have become destitute.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRICHARD, Ala.  This struggling small city on the outskirts of Mobile was warned for years that if it did nothing, its pension fund would run out of money by 2009. Right on schedule, its fund ran dry.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Home-Stretch Buying Lifts Merchants’ Spirits
articles.snippet: In-store sales are up 5.5 percent on the final weekend before Christmas compared with last year.
articles.abstract: In-store sales are up 5.5 percent on the final weekend before Christmas compared with last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last-minute holiday surge is heralding the return of the American consumer, who is shedding the recession’s thrifty ways and rediscovering the pleasure of shopping.

articles.headline: After Russian Death, Inquiry Doors Open and Shut
articles.snippet: Reports had different conclusions about the death in detention of a lawyer who had accused investigators of fraud.
articles.abstract: Reports had different conclusions about the death in detention of a lawyer who had accused investigators of fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It was more than a year ago when six members of an obscure oversight panel filed into Butyrskaya Prison to look into the death of a prisoner.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Secrets Could Surface in Swiss Nuclear Case
articles.snippet: An effort to hide the C.I.A.’s relationship with a Swiss family hit a snag when a magistrate recommended charging the men with nuclear smuggling.
articles.abstract: An effort to hide the C.I.A.’s relationship with a Swiss family hit a snag when a magistrate recommended charging the men with nuclear smuggling.
articles.lead_paragraph: A seven-year effort by the Central Intelligence Agency to hide its relationship with a Swiss family who once acted as moles inside the world’s most successful atomic black market hit a turning point on Thursday when a Swiss magistrate recommended charging the men with trafficking in technology and information for making nuclear arms.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger
